Award.AwardTitle: Efficient Designs for Complex Scientific Experiments
Award.AbstractNarration:
The investigator has two-fold purpose in this project both relate to cost-effective methods of collecting high-efficiency data in Phase I, Phase II and Phase III pharmaceutical trials involving drug discovery/drug abuse, heart-related QT/QTc studies, evaluation of new drugs for unwanted effects and also in experiments dealing with processing of minerals involving chemical reactions. Akin to PK/PD models, one requires complex non-linear models in dealing with medical/chemical/environmental studies. In this context, dwelling on Klimpels floatation recovery model, chemical kinetic model and compartment model, the investigator develops analytically sound and innovative techniques for optimal/nearly optimal estimation of the underlying model parameters with constrained experimental conditions.

The aim of this proposal is to provide research practitioners in fMRI studies, medicine, and pharmacy with ready-to-use statistical/computational software for carrying out cost-effective experiments. Research outcomes on compartment models will allow formal rigorous inference and analysis based on clinical or experimental data for complicated HIV dynamic models. Research practitioners in fMRI studies, medicine, and pharmacy can save time and money by using the new to-be-developed software-based crossover designs.

POR.DRECONTENT:
New mathematical, statistical, and computational tools for identifying and building optimal or highly efficient designs for scientific experiments when the nature of a study calls or allows for repeated applications of units in space and/or time have been developed. Such studies in the form of crossover designs are recommended by FDA for pharmacokinetic and pharmacodynamics (PK/PD) evaluations in one or more phases of clinical trials or for bioavailability studies in making regulatory decision for generic drugs. The designs discovered are also highly desirable for studies in epidemiology, social networks, and agricultural field experiments, including, marketing, physical and virtual stores.

The innovative mathematical/statistical/computational tools developed will address and answer critical design issues when the scientific studies allow for repeated use of units. The project considered the scientific situations both in terms of data collection and data modeling which have not been adequately addressed and studied before. Repeated observations on the same units often produce residual/neighbor effects which need to be modeled and explored via efficient designs. Several highly practical and useful models are entertained while searching for designs to be recommended to the experimenters. Sound innovative and analytically techniques are developed for identifying cost-effective designs in order to ascertain optimal and nearly optimal estimation of the primary and, if needed, secondary parameters imbedded in models under repeated observations. 

The research outcomes are indispensable source of information to a broad cross- and multidisciplinary researchers and practitioners, including drug developments, medical device studies, food, epidemiology, social networking, shelving and re-shelving displaying techniques, and displaying products to consumers through advertisements and even social media. Scientists in the fields of functional Magnetic Resonance Imaging (fMRI), pharmacy, medical devices, and generic medicine are provided with highly useful tools to carry out their studies and make proper inference from the collected data under repeated measurements. Ready-to-use statistical/computational software are designed, tested, and freely distributed for dissemination of knowledge on repeated measurements studies. The project trained and graduated seven (including 2 females) PhD students and three more are currently under final stage of training.  Several undergraduate students were also mentored.
